case_name: Lala Praduman Kumar v. Virendra Goyal

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 648 of 1966 before the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 648 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the order dated December 4,

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated December 4, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 3310 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated December 4, 1964 of the the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 3310 of 1964. Sarjoo Prasad and J. P. Goyal for the appellant.

facts.text: Under a deed dated October 28, 1949, Virendra Goyal, the first respondent, obtained permanent tenancy rights in 28 plots of land owned by Lala Praduman Kumar.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Shah, J. Under a deed dated October 28, 1949, Virendra Goyal, the first respondent herein, obtained permanent tenancy rights in 28 plots of land of the ownership of Lala Praduman Kumar.

facts.text: The tenant agreed to pay Rs. 250/- per annum as advance rent on the first day of January of each year.

anchor.surface_text: The tenant agreed to pay Rs. 250/- per annum as advance rent on the first day of January of each year, and in default of payment of rent for two companysicutive years the tenancy rights were to stand forfeited.

facts.text: In default of payment of rent for two consecutive years the tenancy rights were to stand forfeited.

anchor.surface_text: , and in default of payment of rent for two companysicutive years the tenancy rights were to stand forfeited. Goyal transferred his tenancy rights to Lala Hukam Chand.

facts.text: Goyal transferred his tenancy rights to Lala Hukam Chand.

anchor.surface_text: Goyal transferred his tenancy rights to Lala Hukam Chand. Pursuant to the lease several tenements were raised on the land demised.

facts.text: Pursuant to the lease several tenements were raised on the land demised.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the lease several tenements were raised on the land demised. The tenant failed to pay the rent accrued due for two years.

facts.text: The tenant failed to pay the rent accrued due for two years.

anchor.surface_text: The tenant failed to pay the rent accrued due for two years. The appellant then served a numberice on January 4, 1960, terminating the tenancy and instituted an action in the Court of the City Munsiff, Saharanpur,

facts.text: The appellant served a notice on January 4, 1960, terminating the tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then served a numberice on January 4, 1960, terminating the tenancy and instituted an action in the Court of the City Munsiff, Saharanpur, against Virendra Goyal and Lala Hukam Chand for a decree in ejectment and for an order for payment of Rs. 545/1 1 - as rent and companypensation.

facts.text: Appellant instituted an action in the Court of the City Munsiff, Saharanpur, against Virendra Goyal and Lala Hukam Chand for ejectment and payment of Rs. 545/11 as rent and compensation.

anchor.surface_text: against Virendra Goyal and Lala Hukam Chand for a decree in ejectment and for an order for payment of Rs. 545/1 1 - as rent and companypensation. Several companytentions were raised in their written statement by the defendants one of which alone is material.

facts.text: Several contentions raised in written statement by defendants, one material: prayed relief against forfeiture under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act.

anchor.surface_text: Several companytentions were raised in their written statement by the defendants one of which alone is material. The tenants prayed that they should be given relief against forfeiture of their tenancy rights under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act.

facts.text: In the Trial Court the tenants deposited an amount of Rs. 1,099-34.

anchor.surface_text: In the Trial Court the tenants deposited an amount of Rs. 1,099-34. The Trial Judge held that the companyditions relating to deposit in Court of rent in arrear interest thereon, and companyts of the suit were number Compiled with and decreed the plaintiffs claim.

facts.text: Trial Judge held that the conditions relating to deposit of rent in arrear, interest, costs were not complied with and decreed the plaintiff's claim.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Judge held that the companyditions relating to deposit in Court of rent in arrear interest thereon, and companyts of the suit were number Compiled with and decreed the plaintiffs claim. In appeal to the District Court the tenant offered to pay the balance of the amount of the rent due together with companyts of the suit and appeal and interest at the rate of 6 per annum or such other rate as the Court may direct and deposit in Court Rs. 2,082.50 in the aggregate.

facts.text: In appeal to the District Court, tenant offered to pay balance rent due, costs of suit and appeal, interest at 6% p.a., and deposited Rs. 2,082.50.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the District Court the tenant offered to pay the balance of the amount of the rent due together with companyts of the suit and appeal and interest at the rate of 6 per annum or such other rate as the Court may direct and deposit in Court Rs. 2,082.50 in the aggregate.

facts.text: District Judge held amount paid by tenants in excess of due amount, granted benefit of s.114 TPA, relieved against forfeiture.

anchor.surface_text: The learned District Judge was of the view that the amount paid by the tenants was in excess of the amount due by them and observed . . . the appellants have deposited much more amount than is due to the respondent as arrears of rent the companyts of the suit and of the appeal and the interest. There is numberreason why benefit of section 1 1 4 of the Transfer of Property Act be number given to the appellants when they are ready and willing to pay much more amount than is actually due to the respondent.

facts.text: District Court observed valuable constructions over the plot and defendants' dispossession would cause great loss.

anchor.surface_text: The fact is that there are valuable companystructions over the plot and defendants dispossession would put them to a great loss. It is for this reason that they are prepared to pay the amount that may be demanded from them. 1, therefore, find that the appellants are entitled to the benefit of section 114 of the Transfer of Property Act and are relieved against the forfeiture.

facts.text: Second appeal against District Court decision summarily dismissed by Allahabad High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The second appeal against this decision was summarily dismissed by the High Court of Allahabad. In appeal to this Court companynsel for the appellant companytends  1  that jurisdiction under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act to relieve against forfeiture for number-payment of rent may only be exercised by the Court of First Instance and number by the Court of Appeal

facts.text: Appellant contends that jurisdiction under s.114 TPA only by Court of First Instance, not Appellate Court.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to this Court companynsel for the appellant companytends  1  that jurisdiction under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act to relieve against forfeiture for number-payment of rent may only be exercised by the Court of First Instance and number by the Court of Appeal  2  that the Trial Court gave an opportunity to the tenants to pay the amount of rent due together with interest and companyts, but the tenants failed to avail themselves of the opportunity.

facts.text: Trial Court gave opportunity to tenants to pay rent, interest, costs but tenants failed to avail.

anchor.surface_text: 2  that the Trial Court gave an opportunity to the tenants to pay the amount of rent due together with interest and companyts, but the tenants failed to avail themselves of the opportunity. In the circumstances the appellate Court had numberjurisdiction to grant another opportunity to the tenants to make the requisite payment and grant relief against forfeiture of the tenancy

facts.text: Supreme Court held no substance in appellant's contentions, appellate court can grant relief under s.114.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, there is numbersubstance in any of the companytentions. Section 114 of the Transfer of Property Act provides Where a lease of immovable property has determined by forfeiture for number-payment of rent, and the lessor sues to eject the lessee, if, at the hearing of the suit, the lessee pays or tenders to the lessor the rent in arrear, together with interest thereon and his full companyts of the suit, or gives such security as the Court thinks sufficient for making such payment within fifteen days, the Court may, in lieu of making a decree for ejectment, pass an order relieving the lessee against the forfeiture and thereupon the lessee shall hold the property leased as if the forfeiture had number occurred.

facts.text: Valuable constructions had been put upon the land leased.

anchor.surface_text: The District Court has observed that valuable companystructions had been put upon the land leased and the tenants had deposited an amount very much larger than the amount due to the landlord.

facts.text: Tenants deposited amount very much larger than due to landlord.

anchor.surface_text: The District Court has observed that valuable companystructions had been put upon the land leased and the tenants had deposited an amount very much larger than the amount due to the landlord. Having regard to the circumstances the District Court was of the view that discretion should be exercised in favour of the tenants.

facts.text: High Court confirmed the view of the District Court by summarily dismissing the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court summarily dismissed the appeal. The High Court must be taken to have companyfirmed the view of the District Court.
Appeal by special leave from the order dated December 4, 1964 of the the Allahabad High Court in Second Appeal No. 3310 of 1964.
under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act.

issues.text: Whether jurisdiction under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act to relieve against forfeiture for non-payment of rent may only be exercised by the Court of First Instance and not by the Court of Appeal?

arguments.claim: Covenant of forfeiture for non-payment of rent is merely security for rent payment; courts grant relief unless tenant disentitled by conduct.

anchor.surface_text: The covenant of forfeiture of tenancy for non-payment of rent is regarded by the Courts as merely a clause for securing payment of rent, and unless the tenant has by his conduct disentitled himself to equitable relief the Courts grant relief against forfeiture

arguments.claim: Appeal being rehearing of suit, appellate court may relieve tenant against forfeiture at hearing of appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Jurisdiction to relieve against forfeiture for non-payment of rent may be exercised by the Court if the tenant in a suit in ejectment at the hearing of the suit pays the arrears of rent together with interest thereon and full costs of the suit. In terms s. 114 makes payment

arguments.claim: Precedents from High Courts support appellate court jurisdiction to grant relief under s.114: Chilukuri, Janab Vellathi, Shrikishanlal, Budhi Ballabh, Bhagwant.

anchor.surface_text: Passing of a decree in ejectment against the tenant by the Court of First Instance does not take away the jurisdiction of the appellate Court to grant equitable relief. This is the view taken by the High Courts in India see Chilukuri Tripura Sundaramma v. Chilkuri Venketes-Warlu

arguments.claim: Failure to avail trial court opportunity does not bar appellate jurisdiction; it goes to discretion.
In exercising discretion under s.114, judge case by case: delay, conduct of parties, difficulties to landlord weighed against tenant (citing Namdeo).
Equity maxim: must do equity, come with clean hands; if tenant's conduct disentitles, no relief.
District Court properly exercised discretion: valuable constructions on land, tenants deposited much larger amount than due.

anchor.surface_text: The District Court has observed that valuable constructions had been put upon the land leased and the tenants had deposited an amount very much larger than the amount due to the landlord. Having regard to the circumstances the District Court was of the view

holdings.text: Jurisdiction to relieve against forfeiture for non-payment of rent may be exercised by the appellate court as an appeal is a rehearing of the suit.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 114 conditions apply at hearing of suit; appeal is rehearing allowing appellate court to grant relief; supported by multiple High Court precedents.

holdings.text: Passing of a decree in ejectment by the trial court does not take away the jurisdiction of the appellate court to grant relief against forfeiture under s.114.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly states decree by first instance does not divest appellate jurisdiction; cites precedents from Madras, Nagpur, Allahabad, Bombay High Courts.

holdings.text: Failure by tenants to avail opportunity to pay at trial court does not bar appellate court jurisdiction to grant relief under s.114; it is a matter of discretion.

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that there is any bar to the exercise of jurisdiction by the appellate companyrt merely because in the Court of First Instance relief against forfeiture was claimed by the tenants and they failed to avail themselves of the opportunity of paying the amount of rent

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes jurisdiction from discretion; prior failure affects discretion, not power to exercise.

holdings.text: In exercising discretion under s.114 TPA, each case judged on its own: weigh delay, conduct of parties, difficulties to landlord against tenant.

anchor.surface_text: This Court in Namdeo Lokman Lodhi v. Narmadabai and others 1  has observed at p. 1025 in exercising the discretion  under s. 114 of the Transfer of Property Act , each case must be judged by itself, the delay, the companyduct of the parties and the difficulties

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts Supreme Court precedent in Namdeo; applies equitable maxims of clean hands and doing equity.

holdings.text: District Court properly exercised discretion under s.114 in favour of tenants given valuable constructions on land and excess deposit.

anchor.surface_text: The District Court has observed that valuable companystructions had been put upon the land leased and the tenants had deposited an amount very much larger than the amount due to the landlord. Having regard to the circumstances the District Court was of the view that discretion should be exercised in favour of the tenants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts of excess payment and improvements justify relief; no disentitling conduct; High Court affirmed.

holdings.text: Covenant of forfeiture for non-payment of rent is regarded as security for rent; courts grant relief unless tenant disentitled by conduct.

anchor.surface_text: The companyenant of forfeiture of tenancy for number-payment of rent is regarded by the Courts as merely a clause for securing payment of rent, and unless the tenant has by his companyduct disentitled himself to equitable relief the Courts grant relief against forfeiture of tenancy on the tenant paying the rent due, interest thereon and companyts of the suit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Purposive interpretation of forfeiture clause as security, not penalty; equitable relief routine upon payment.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, there is numbersubstance in any of the contentions. Section 114 of the Transfer of Property Act provides Where a lease of immovable property has determined by forfeiture for number-payment of rent, and the lessor sues to eject the lessee, if, at the hearing of the suit, the lessee pays or tenders to the lessor the rent in arrear, together with interest thereon and his full companyts of the suit, or gives such security as the Court thinks sufficient for making such payment within fifteen days, the Court may, in lieu of making a decree for ejectment, pass an order relieving the lessee against the forfeiture and thereupon the lessee shall hold the property leased as if the forfeiture had number occurred.
